hints.DMAIC: Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control - a structured problem-solving methodology for process improvement.
hints.Continuous Improvement: An ongoing effort to improve products, services, or processes by making incremental enhancements.
hints.Value Stream Mapping: A visualization tool used to analyze and optimize the flow of materials and information through a process.
hints.5S Methodology: A workplace organization system (Sort, Set in Order, Shine, Standardize, and Sustain) that promotes efficiency and reduces waste.
hints.Waste Reduction: Identifying and eliminating non-value-adding activities in a process to optimize resources and minimize costs.
hints.Root Cause Analysis: A method for identifying the underlying cause of a problem or defect and preventing its recurrence.
hints.Process Mapping: A visual representation of the steps, inputs, and outputs in a process to understand and improve its performance.
hints.Standard Work: A set of documented, best-practice procedures that ensures consistent and efficient task execution.
hints.Visual Management: The use of visual cues and displays to communicate essential information and facilitate process control.
hints.Statistical Process Control: A statistical technique for monitoring and controlling process quality using data analysis and control charts.
hints.Control Charts: A graphical tool for tracking process performance over time and identifying variations that may require corrective action.
hints.Six Sigma: A disciplined, data-driven approach to process improvement that aims to reduce defects and variation.
hints.SIPOC: A high-level process map that identifies Suppliers, Inputs, Process, Outputs, and Customers to establish a process baseline.
hints.Gemba Walk: A management practice where leaders visit the actual workplace (Gemba) to observe and understand work processes and identify improvement opportunities.
hints.Kanban: A visual workflow management system that optimizes the flow of work by limiting work-in-progress and identifying bottlenecks.
